title: (x) 'Libbie Wicket': swashy script - what font? - Olicana {Nick C}
content:
Hello! I need help ID'ing the font for the logo of Libbie Wicket.

[www.libbiewicket.com](http://web.archive.org/web/20100202141828/http:/www.libbiewicket.com/ "www.libbiewicket.com")

I'm so in love with this font - but I can't seem to find it anywhere! Also the font for the other part of the logo would be fantastic as well (normal serif type) and the calligraphy type as well.

Thanks in advance!

[http://www.luxecetera.com/blog/wp-content/uploads/2009/07/dsc\_0301.jpg](http://web.archive.org/web/20100202141828/http:/www.luxecetera.com/blog/wp-content/uploads/2009/07/dsc_0301.jpg "http://www.luxecetera.com/blog/wp-content/uploads/2009/07/dsc\_0301.jpg")  
 [http://www.luxecetera.com/blog/wp-content/uploads/2009/07/dsc\_0275.jpg](http://web.archive.org/web/20100202141828/http:/www.luxecetera.com/blog/wp-content/uploads/2009/07/dsc_0275.jpg "http://www.luxecetera.com/blog/wp-content/uploads/2009/07/dsc\_0275.jpg")
author: kateprice

comments.content:
I recognize that one. It's [Olicana Smooth](http://web.archive.org/web/20100202141828/http:/www.type.co.uk/index.php?p=GType). Glad you like it ;^)

Nick Cooke
That doesn't seem to match up..
When I go type in the wording I want for the smooth version, it doesn't look like the sample - which font comes with the Olicina Smooth?

It's the 'swash' feature in OpenType. It looks like that feature can't be enabled when generating a sample, but I do know it's there.

Nick Cooke

I've done a bit of research: The cap L and l/c k are swash glyphs, and the cap W is actually the swash M rotated 180 degrees with a bit of alteration. The other lower case are standard glyphs with ligatures activated.

Nick Cooke
Kate, reason why Nick is so sure it is Olicana is, because he is the designer of the font. :)
